title: 114_hr529

"SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSE." Congress finds that the tax treatment of section 529 college savings plans was changed in 2001 to exempt qualified distributions from taxation. This favorable tax treatment was made permanent in 2006. Section 529 plans help middle-class families save for college expenses. The latest data shows 11.83 million 529 accounts open nationwide with $244.5 billion in total assets. States offer 529 plans with low minimum contributions to help families save for college. The President's budget proposes taxing certain future distributions from these plans. The President's proposed tax on future distributions from 529 college savings plans could discourage their use, leading to more student debt. The Act aims to strengthen and modernize 529 plans, making them more consumer-friendly. The Act aims to modernize and make 529 plans more consumer-friendly. SEC. 2. Computer technology and equipment now qualify as higher education expenses for 529 accounts. Computer technology and equipment, including computer software and Internet access, are now considered qualified higher education expenses for 529 accounts if used primarily by the beneficiary during their enrollment at an eligible educational institution. The amendment made by this section applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2014. Elimination of distribution aggregation requirements under Section 529(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 by striking subparagraph (D), effective for distributions after December 31, 2014. Additionally, re-contribution of refunded amounts is addressed. The amendment allows beneficiaries to recontribute refunded qualified higher education expenses to a qualified tuition program without affecting their distribution for the taxable year. The amendment allows beneficiaries to recontribute refunded qualified higher education expenses to a qualified tuition program within 60 days of the refund, not exceeding the refunded amount. The effective date is after December 31, 2014. The amendment allows beneficiaries to recontribute refunded qualified higher education expenses to a qualified tuition program within 60 days of the refund, not exceeding the refunded amount. The House of Representatives passed the amendment on February 25, 2015, with the Clerk being Karen L. Haas.
